A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Finitely generated module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a finitely generated module explicitly mentions an 'A-module M', where 'A' refers to a ring. This implies that the concept of a module, and specifically a finitely generated module, is dependent on the concept of a ring. A module is a generalization of the idea of a vector space, where instead of a field, the scalars come from a ring. Therefore, without the concept of a ring, the definition of a module, and hence a finitely generated module, would not make sense. The ring provides the necessary algebraic structure that allows the definition of scalar multiplication within the module. Thus, the concept of a ring is essential for the definition of a finitely generated module to be meaningful.
